com.ibm.xmi.framework
Interface Feature

All Superinterfaces:
Data
All Known Subinterfaces:
AssociationEnd, Attribute
All Known Implementing Classes:
FeatureImpl
public interface Feature
extends Data

This interface represents a feature in the framework object model. Features belong to classes and define the legal values that instances of the classes (XMIObjects) can have.

Features have multiplicities, a type, and a value type. The type of a feature is a Classifier, and it can be either an XMIClass, a Datatype, or an Enum.

The value type is one of the valid types for Value objects. It is needed to make the distinctions necessary for XMI. It also allows you to avoid setting the type in certain cases. The value type of the Feature depends on the type of the Feature.

If the type of the Feature is an Enum, the value type must be Value.ENUM. If the type of the Feature is a Datatype, the value type must be Value.DATA. However, you can set the value type of a Feature to Value.DATA and not set the Feature type if you wish to avoid the effort of making a Datatype and setting the Feature type to it.

If the type of the Feature is a class, the value type must be either Value.OBJECT, Value.CONTAINER, Value.CONTAINED, or Value.REFERENCE.

The multiplicity is a string. If none is present, the default is 0..* for instance features and 0..1 for data features. Multiplicities are either single numbers or pairs of numbers separated by "..". You represent the unbounded multiplicity with "*".
